texts.shortText: Grateloupia capensis, also incorrectly identified in some past publications as Grateloupia filicina, which is a valid species, but has a European distribution.

Narrow, flat fronds arise from a disclike holdfast and give rise to numerous long, thin lateral branches, resulting in a characteristic ‘ragged’ appearance. Colour dark purplish-brown to almost black.
Overall up to 300 mm tall, individual fronds only about 10 mm wide.

Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Point.

Common in rock pool along the west coast, where it can occur high on the shore and can be a dominant species. Has been considered as a possible source for the extraction of carrageenan, a chemical used in the food industry as a gelling and thickening agent.
Spore-producing structures, each producing 4- spores (tetrasporangia) are found evenly-spread across much of the blades.
The numerous long, tattered side branches to the main fronds make this species fairly easy to identify.

Bolton, JJ, De Clerck, O, Francis, CM, Siyanga-Tembo, F & Anderson, RJ (2016). Two newly discovered Grateloupia (Halymeniaceae, Rhodophyta) species on aquaculture rafts on the west coast of South Africa, including the widely introduced Grateloupia turuturu. Phycologia, 55(6), 659-664.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 396).

De Clerck, O, Bolton, JJ, Anderson, RJ & Coppejans, E (2005). Guide to the seaweeds of KwaZulu-Natal. Scripta Botanica Belgica, 33, 1-294.

Gargiulo, GM, Morabito, M & Manghisi, A (2013). A re-assessment of reproductive anatomy and postfertilization development in the systematics of Grateloupia Halymeniales, Rhodophyta). Cryptogamie Algologie, 34(1), 3-25.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 286, as Aeodes orbitosa).
